awd_abstract_narration:
The development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics is a major intellectual achievement. The validity of this model was further confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN. However, the Standard Model leaves open many questions, including why matter dominates over anti-matter in the Universe (CP violation), the values of the masses of quarks and leptons, and the properties of dark matter, among others. Most explanations require new phenomena, which we call Beyond the Standard Model Physics (BSM), and which the LHCb experiment at CERN has been designed to explore. This award provides facility operations, maintenance, and computing support to enable the participation of U.S. scientists in the LHCb experiment at CERN. 

The LHC is the premier High Energy Physics particle accelerator in the world and is currently operating at the CERN laboratory near Geneva Switzerland, one of the foremost facilities for answering these BSM questions. The LHCb experiment is one of four large experiments at the LHC and is designed to study in detail the decays of hadrons containing b or c quarks. The goal is to identify the existence of new physics beyond the Standard Model by examining the properties of hadrons containing these quarks. The new physics, or new forces, can be manifest by particles, as yet to be discovered, whose presence would modify decay rates and CP violating asymmetries of hadrons containing the b and c quarks, allowing new phenomena to be observed indirectly. 

U.S. groups play a leading role in the physics analysis, hardware development, and computing of LHCb. This award will support the NSF-supported groups' share of common items necessary for the experiment, maintenance and operations support for U.S.-delivered components, co-location of an LHCb Tier-2 computing facility, and R&D to optimize the operation of the experiment. 

The broader impacts of this award cover many areas, from student research experiences for graduate and undergraduate students, to very active QuarkNet Centers and Masterclass programs for high school teachers and students. A steady stream of undergraduates has been working in the participating university laboratories, where graduate students also have direct engagement in both instrumentation development as well as data analysis. Undergraduate and graduate students will be direct participants in the fabrication, testing, and maintenance of detector components under U.S. responsibility. Early career and nontraditional researchers will be integral participants in this exciting program of research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported LHCb operations during the long shutdown prior to LHC Run 3 and the first two years of data taking in Run 3. Specifically, this grant provided the US fair share for maintenance and operations of the LHCb experiment, including for the US-led Upstream Tracker (UT) project.  The UT detector was designed, fabricated, tested, installed, and commissioned by an international team led by Syracuse and Maryland. This grant provided critical engineering support at the University of Maryland for the development and construction of the UT off-detector electronics. The burn-in and quality assurance (QA) testing of all boards were performed at Maryland, shipped and received to CERN, and again QA-ed by Maryland personnel before the detector assembly at CERN. Members of the Maryland group supported by this grant spent time at CERN working on the assembly, installation, and commissioning of the UT detector. This included a group member supported by this grant who served as the main electronics engineer for the Periphery Electronics Processing Interface (PEPI) providing critical engineering support throughout the detector assembly and tests at the surface and the detector installation and commissioning in the LHCb cavern. The UT detector and the electronics are now fully installed, and the detector has been successfully read out and commissioned.

This grant also supported the creation of a US-based Tier-2 grid computing center for LHCb hosted at MIT, which provides the US fair share of grid computing resources to the LHCb experiment. This grant funded purchasing the servers, disks, etc, and for post-doc support to enable running LHCb collaboration grid computing jobs at MIT. The MIT LHCb Tier-2 grid site has been one of the largest and most reliable sites LHCb has access to over the past few years. In addition, the post-docs that provided support for LHCb Tier-2 operations also provided more general computing support for LHCb, including many important software development projects of the past 5 years. For example, post-docs partially supported by this grant provided computing support for critical software developments related to the new LHCb Event Model, e.g. how particles are defined and stored and how data is packed, to improve the performance of LHCb tracking software, and implemented other improvements in core LHCb software. More recently, this computing support has been focused on validating and commissioning real-time software applications on incoming Run 3 data, including real-time detector monitoring.

The primary broad impact of this grant was providing critical Infrastructure for Research for the LHCb experiment at CERN. The resources provided by this grant were critical to the success of the LHCb Upgrade I, and for enabling the science programs of the 1000 members of the LHCb collaboration. LHCb has published over 700 journal articles to date, which have been cited 70 thousand times. None of that would be possible without maintenance and operations contributions or Tier-2 computing resources, and this grant allowed the US-LHCb groups to provide our fair share contributions in these areas. In addition, the UT is a vital component of the upgraded LHCb detector. Not only does the UT contribute to the tracking performance, but it also provides important information that is used to speed up the tracking algorithms. The resources provided by this grant allowed US-LHCb to properly support the successful fabrication and installation of the UT.

In terms of STEM Workforce, the post-docs and graduate students supported by this grant that have moved on have been highly successful, including the following: the first student at MIT to be awarded the new PhD in Physics, Statistics, and Data Science, who became a Data Science Consultant; a Research Scientist at Meta AI; a CERN Technical Fellow working in the LHCb Computing Group; an Ambizione Fellow; and two faculty members. Finally, all of the US-LHCb groups put substantial effort into STEM Education, specifically in the areas of training undergrads and high-school students.
